description: From Middle English galant, galaunt, from Old French galant (“courteous; dashing; brave”), present participle of galer (“to rejoice; make merry”), from gale (“pomp; show; festivity; mirth”); either from Frankish *wala (“good, well”), a variant form of *wela, from Proto-Germanic *wela (whence well), from Proto-Indo-European *welh₁- (“to choose, wish”); or alternatively from Frankish *gail (“merry; mirthful; proud; luxuriant”), from Proto-Germanic *gailaz (“merry; excited; luxurious”), related to Dutch geil (“horny; lascivious; salacious; lecherous”), German geil (“randy; horny; lecherous; wicked”), Old English gāl (“wanton; wicked; bad”).

adjectives.description: gallant (comparative more gallant, superlative most gallant)

examples: This town [is built in a very gallant place.

description: 17th-century borrowing from French galant. See above.

adjectives.description: gallant (comparative more gallant, superlative most gallant)

entries.meaning: Polite and attentive to ladies; courteous to women; chivalrous.
(dated) A fashionable young man who is polite and attentive to women.
One who woos, a lover, a suitor, a seducer.

verbs.description: gallant (third-person singular simple present gallants, present participle gallanting, simple past and past participle gallanted)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To attend or wait on (a lady).
examples: to gallant ladies to the play

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To handle with grace or in a modish manner.

examples: ... and the canoes of Vivenza, locking their yard-arms into those of the vanquished, very courteously gallanted them into their coral harbors.
